rev.diff:
Line 186: Line 186:
During the night of 1â2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria; shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive">{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 2 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs sent by the Egyptian government, armed with clubs, stones, rocks and knives, attacked protesters in central Cairo, including Tahrir square.<ref>{{Cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarakâs Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many of the protesters from the previous day's protest decided to sleep and remain in Tahrir Square while more protesters are coming.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day}}</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html</ref> The army was asking the protesters to go home saying "''The armed forces call on the protesters to go home for the sake of bringing back stability.''"<ref>http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/02/goodspeed-analysis-only-the-egyptian-army-has-power-to-restore-stability/</ref> There was also unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/> Private [[mercenaries]] were also said to be in Egypt to evacuate foreigners.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> Some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{Cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who are the pro-Mubarak demonstrators? - CNN.com |publisher=CNN |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
During the night of 1â2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria; shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive">{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 2 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs sent by the Egyptian government, armed with clubs, stones, rocks and knives, attacked protesters in central Cairo, including Tahrir square.<ref>{{Cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarakâs Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many of the protesters from the previous day's protest decided to sleep and remain in Tahrir Square while more protesters are coming.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day}}</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html</ref> The army was asking the protesters to go home saying "''The armed forces call on the protesters to go home for the sake of bringing back stability.''"<ref>http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/02/goodspeed-analysis-only-the-egyptian-army-has-power-to-restore-stability/</ref> There was also unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/> Private [[mercenaries]] were also said to be in Egypt to evacuate foreigners.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> Some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{Cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who are the pro-Mubarak demonstrators? - CNN.com |publisher=CNN |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
â
At noon local time, internet access in Egypt has been at least partially restored and the night-time curfew in Egypt has been eased. It will now run from 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day instead of 3:00 pm to 8:00 am.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> The pro-Mubarak activists attacked [[Al Arabiya]] reporter Ahmed Bagato while he was trying to show them harassing the anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8288167/Egypt-protests-live.html |title=Egypt protests: live |publisher=Telegraph |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/><ref name="aljazlive">''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
+
At noon local time, internet access in Egypt has been at least partially restored and the night-time curfew in Egypt has been eased. It will now run from 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day instead of 3:00 pm to 8:00 am.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> The pro-Mubarak activists attacked [[Al Arabiya]] reporter Ahmed Bagato while he was trying to show them harassing the anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8288167/Egypt-protests-live.html |title=Egypt protests: live |publisher=Telegraph |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government. However, Mohamed ElBaradei and the Muslim Brotherhood stressed they would not talk to any government representative, including Vice President Omar Suleiman, until Mubarak's resignation.<ref>http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/is-mubarak-at-the-end-of-his-tether-1.340934</ref> Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/><ref name="aljazlive">''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
Pro-Mubarak supporters on horses<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/14 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> and camels<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/13 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> equipped with swords and whips attacked anti-government protesters<ref>[http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egyptâs Thug Tech"] - ''Spencer Ackerman'' - Wired.com - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak supporters, protesters clash in Egypt|author=|newspaper=msnbc.com|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and rode into Tahrir Square.<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & horses storm into Tahrir Square as protesters clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|medium=News|publisher=RussiaToday|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|xcjJsg8AD2g|Raw Video: Dramatic New Mages of Cairo Violence }}</ref> [[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak backers, opponents clash - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> One person has been reported killed and 611 injured by the Health minister of Egypt.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/watch_now/ |title=Live Stream - Watch Now |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> The Egyptian Museum was firebombed and pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/8 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> and firebombs from buildings to demonstrators on the ground. State-television announced at 19:21 that "You have to evacuate Tahrir Square immediately. We've got confirmed information that violent groups are heading toward Tahrir Square carrying firebombs and seeking to burn the Square."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> There were also clashes in Alexandria.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest: deadly clashes rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
Pro-Mubarak supporters on horses<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/14 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> and camels<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/13 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> equipped with swords and whips attacked anti-government protesters<ref>[http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egyptâs Thug Tech"] - ''Spencer Ackerman'' - Wired.com - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak supporters, protesters clash in Egypt|author=|newspaper=msnbc.com|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and rode into Tahrir Square.<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & horses storm into Tahrir Square as protesters clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|medium=News|publisher=RussiaToday|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|xcjJsg8AD2g|Raw Video: Dramatic New Mages of Cairo Violence }}</ref> [[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak backers, opponents clash - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> One person has been reported killed and 611 injured by the Health minister of Egypt.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/watch_now/ |title=Live Stream - Watch Now |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> The Egyptian Museum was firebombed and pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones<ref>[http://www.elpais.com/fotogaleria/Enfrentamientos/Cairo/elpgal/20110202elpepuint_2/Zes/8 Photo gallery] - El PaÃ­s</ref> and firebombs from buildings to demonstrators on the ground. State-television announced at 19:21 that "You have to evacuate Tahrir Square immediately. We've got confirmed information that violent groups are heading toward Tahrir Square carrying firebombs and seeking to burn the Square."<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> There were also clashes in Alexandria.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest: deadly clashes rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
